commentText: My friend and I got caught in a blizzard as we were driving through Vail pass in Colorado one night ‚Äî it was a total whiteout, we couldn‚Äôt even see the hood of the car most of the time. Several cars had skidded off the road right in front of us, and were driving so slow. Eventually some kindly trucker pulled up next to us and gestured for us to follow him with his lights. He led us to an off-ramp where we were able to find and get a hotel. After getting us safely to the off ramp, he went straight back on the road. He probably saved our life that night. An driverless truck would‚Äôve just left us to wreck and freeze ‚Äî probably would‚Äôve caused the wreck by failing to account for the conditions. Losing truckers scares me as a driver.

videoTitle: We Chased Driverless Trucks In Texas. What We Saw Will Scare You.
videoDescription: Truck driving used to be a solid middle-class job. Not anymore. Driverless trucks just hit the highway in Texas. It's displacing truck ...
commentText: The only reason there is a "driver shortage" is because trucking companies treat their drivers like crap. When I started driving, it was a great job and I loved it. Now, all the companies care about is the bottom line. Dispatchers try and make you work more hours then you legally can. I was local, but I was hardly ever home. The company I worked for decided to expand from a small one covering three states to covering the 13 western. Just as they stated buying new tractors and hiring new drivers, the freight market collapsed and they layed all of the local company drivers off. They gave our jobs to O/O that they didn't have to pay by the hour. I took that as my sign to get out.

commentText: Living in Decatur, IL I can tell you why home prices are so low here. This is one of the most depressed areas in the country. Combine that with ridiculously high taxes and no one wants to live here. The city has lost nearly half its population from the peak a few decades ago. Many of the businesses have closed and left the state and the ones that remain have downsized significantly. There is little to work and what is available, rarely pays enough to support the purchase of a home. Crime is out of control, and our local government has allowed infrastructure to fall to disrepair. Most of the people who remain are low income youth who cannot afford to move because the house they live in isn't worth much so they cannot afford the down payment on a house somewhere else, and the elderly who have lived here all their life and will die here. DO NOT buy a home in central Illinois!

commentText: Many people don‚Äôt seem to understand that a low tax state is generally a low services state. The transportation infrastructure in Austin is WAY behind its growth. In fact, it has been behind long before COVID. Places like Silicon Valley have all kinds of things that support tech companies - skilled tech workers, VCs firms, support businesses, etc. It is difficult to replicate that quickly somewhere else.

videoTitle: Silicon Valley Moved to Austin. Then Regretted It.

videoTitle: Silicon Valley Moved to Austin. Then Regretted It.

commentText: as someone who was offered a job in the tech sector in austin, i can tell you one of the main reasons they didnt attract talent to move there is they tried paying standard Texas wages in a city with 2x the median texas cost of living. i was earning $42/hr when they offered me my job, and the offer was for $35/hr with no relocation assistance. the apartments in austin were only like $300/month less than the ones i had on the west coast.... suffice it to say i stayed where i was and now earn $45/hr. the big names in tech tried to cheap out by going to texas, but austin's not worth moving to unless you pay west coast wages. why would i move to a place where it's hot, i have to run constant A/C, i cant walk anywhere and im 5 hours from anything fun, oh and all for a pay cut. yea no thanks.

Austin has far more cheap land, cheap labor, and cheap electricity than California making it a far more desirable destination for hardware.

It's hot, full of bugs, and there isn't F all to do nature wise compared to a state like California. You can drive eight hours in any direction and there's hardly a change of weather or scenery. In California you drive one or two hours in a different direction and you are in the mountains, forest, desert, beaches, etc. then there is the illusion of freedom. Texas is pretty much 100% privately owned land. Try finding a dirt road to just drive down and ride a motorcycle or go shoot your guns. California while it has some of the worst and most restrictive gun laws in the country, outside of LA or Marin county there is quite a bit of freedom. You see a dirt road in the mountains and It's likely government or public land and you can drive down there in your jeep and go shoot your guns smoking a doobie and if a park ranger sees you he's likely just to wave.

videoTitle: Silicon Valley Moved to Austin. Then Regretted It.
videoDescription: Austin saw the biggest price drop in homes in the United States. So what's happening to the city that was luring Silicon Valley?
commentText: I grew up in the Bay Area and lived in Dallas for a year. I visited Austin, San Antonio, Houston, Galveston. I‚Äôll never set foot in Texas again if I can possibly help it. I knew a lot of people who moved there from the Bay Area would regret it. There just isn‚Äôt enough to do within easy access for enough of the year. In the Bay Area, you can take a day trip to go skiiing from December until March. You can sail or kayak or windsurf the rest of the year from scores of launches along the Bay and all along the Delta. You can comfortably hike year round, play tennis outdoors, bike in Golden Gate Park. In Dallas, I couldn‚Äôt do anything outdoors during the summertime. It was 90 degrees at night. I know Austin wasn‚Äôt any more comfortable. Stanford and Cal are two of the best universities in the world, creating a stimulating, invigorating environment. Unfortunately, Oakland has lost its professional sports franchises, but you still have the 49ers, Giants, Warriors, Sharks and Earthquakes, all the major sports. Austin? None of them. The food is better, world famous in San Francisco. More variety, fresh fruit and vegetables year round, pretty cheap too. There‚Äôs just no comparison in my mind. Sure real estate might have been cheaper, and probably still is, but I don‚Äôt want to stay indoors looking at the walls all day. More space just means more space to clean. A bigger garden means more weeds to pull. A riding lawn mower is not as much fun as a kayak. People severely misjudged what life in Texas is like.  So I‚Äôll tell you. it sucks. Austin and the surrounding Hill Country are the nicest parts, but Texas as a whole sucks, especially with the current gubmint.

commentText: There's always a reason why living expense is so cheap in areas like Austin, and that's living environment. California is literally a rectangle borderline next to the sea, with good weather all year round and little to none natural disaster after the 1989 earthquake. videoTitle: Silicon Valley Moved to Austin. Then Regretted It.
videoDescription: Austin saw the biggest price drop in homes in the United States. So what's happening to the city that was luring Silicon Valley?
commentText: I remember when I started at Dell in Round Rock.  It was the only thing around, surrounded by fields of cows and a small neighborhood or two.  Back then  there were just 3 buildings!   Then suddenly we had a walmart and an HEB and then TOLL ROADS...that was the beginning of the end haha.   Then we kept growing and growing like someone was force-stuffing a goose for that tasty foie gras.    MY RENT for a 2 bedroom place just a mile away was $450 a month..  I can't imagine now.     I remmber the Austin bus was free in 88.  I went everywhere, man.

videoTitle: Silicon Valley Moved to Austin. Then Regretted It.

videoTitle: Silicon Valley Moved to Austin. Then Regretted It.
videoDescription: Austin saw the biggest price drop in homes in the United States. So what's happening to the city that was luring Silicon Valley?
commentText: As a silicon valley born and raised resident, I kept laughing at the "Austin is the next Silicon Valley" tripe everyone spewed years ago.  You can't replicate Stanford, Cal, Davis, etc. education in the bay with Texas.  It just doesn't work.  The culture of Texas doesn't allow for diverse people to come together and make new things.  The city itself is unbelievably hot, humid, and lacks any real diversity.  Now I've seen a ton of poeple coming back and they are so upset they sold their homes and now are struggling to get back in.

videoTitle: Silicon Valley Moved to Austin. Then Regretted It.
videoDescription: Austin saw the biggest price drop in homes in the United States. So what's happening to the city that was luring Silicon Valley?
commentText: As an Austinite from the place Portland stole "Keep ______ Weird," I found it easy to relocate to NYC and LA with no real culture change except for rent prices. So, it doesn't surprise me that the scavengers fleeing these cities to live their tech libertarian dreams found beating my city into submission even less possible. üòÇ

videoTitle: Silicon Valley Moved to Austin. Then Regretted It.
videoDescription: Austin saw the biggest price drop in homes in the United States. So what's happening to the city that was luring Silicon Valley?
commentText: It's true that the shifts in work arrangements are creating some very real ripples, and we're seeing that play out right here in Dallas. It's truly disheartening to hear about people you know facing the difficult decision of selling their homes, sometimes at a lower price than they purchased them for, all to relocate closer to their company's office.  Many employers are indeed making it clear that a return to in-office work is becoming a requirement, and for those who had moved further out for the flexibility of remote work, this can present a significant challenge. It forces a tough choice between their current living situation and their job security.

commentText: More and more corporations/firms have found out that cutting costs raise profits faster than raising sales, so they find all kinds of ways to cut it. The easiest one they found recently, is to slowly cut down on employment because they only want the bare minimum level of employees, just enough to make the product work.  Problem comes when everyone starts doing that to raise their share value, since less people are employed sales drop, then they cut even more employees to make up that loss. commentText: The Gen Z experience:  - Graduate from high school in the midst of a pandemic (your graduation was almost certainly virtual) - Go to college (where a significant part of your college years was in front of a laptop) - Graduate with tens of thousands of dollars in debt - Can't get a job to pay off said debt and can‚Äôt get a job in the field you studied (or in any field) - Work minimum wage in order to BARELY get by - Live with your parents - Can't afford an apartment (don‚Äôt even think about ever buying a house) - Can't get a date because you‚Äôre too poor or you can't afford it - Have little to no friends because no one has the time to hang out - Get called ‚Äòlazy and entitled‚Äô by boomers and Gen X-ers  - Realize nothing matters no matter how hard you try or work, almost every common thing your parents had when they were younger is now unobtainable for you - You develop thoughts of üíÄ-ing yourself - You isolate yourself from society and spend all day in your moms basement playing video games to escape reality - You get addicted to porn to relieve the stress and anxiety that‚Äôs making your life difficult - You‚Äôre probably using drugs to numb the pain - You start to develop mental illness (as if you haven‚Äôt already developed it at this point) because the job market is destroying your mental health - Become another person in this generation, lost and forgotten  All while older people, employers and politicians wonder why Gen Z doesn't want to work or can't hold a job, are not dating or getting married, are not having babies, are socially inept, more than half are mentally unfit and a lot more are physically unfit, and a great sense of nihilism is sweeping the generation.   It was a losing battle before it even began. Gen Z was fucked the moment Covid came and destroyed everyone‚Äôs lives.

commentText: As a millennial, with 8 years of professional experience in tech with 17 years of hobbyist experience, it is shit for us as well. I applied to 1,457 jobs before I landed a job with a local startup in a non-booming city. When i say startup, I mean me and the owner. That's it. I had to take this massive risk just to ensure I could pay rent after unemployment ran out here in the US. The best advice I can give is to do 2 things. Keep going, and get out into nature when you are not applying for jobs. Take a bus to go somewhere to hike. Get away from people as much as you can and refresh yourself.   Then try and find local job postings for SMALL businesses. And I mean small. Big tech will replace lower end employees faster than small mom and pop places who care about people. Aim to have enough, not excess. Learn to be content, not grinding. You will find happiness moment to moment, not in large clumps. And remember, when you eventually get something, be damn proud of yourself because it is fucking rough out there. Work hard, get into nature, and be at peace my friends. Hoping you all the best.

commentText: As a German product architect and senior software engineer, I am almost too annoyed to even say this anymore - but I will do so once more, so that some people may learn the truth:  it is NOT AI which is taking so many jobs. Our biggest clients all work in manufacturing, as we write SAP software, which is used throughtout most of the German manufacturing and automotive industry (and many more). As I am in charge of our AI development projects myself, and have even implemented the proof of concept AI basis using keras on tensorflow for our data mining AIs while using a locally hosted LLM for our LLM-based project proof, I know AI and I know the technology.  However, in none of these corporations you could claim that AI is being used in a production-ready context. We (as a thirdparty SAP-based software supplier) are way ahead of other competitors in the same field, as we have a few AI products already ready for use. However, those products are the only ones our customers have ever seen in their automation and system context. And to this day I have to essentially always start from 0, when talking to any customer about AI.  No, the industry IS NOT USING AI IN PRODUCTION. Corporations are using "AI" as a neat excuse for not hiring because their business is just so bad these days (which they tell us often, when we suggest large-scale projects as we did before Covid). First all corporations blamed covid for their bad numbers, then it was the Ukraine war and now it is AI. The reason changes but the effect is the same: A bad economic recession and the current scapegoat is "AI automation".  So please, when you hear a corporation is not hiring because they automated the position using AI, just know that they are not hiring because they simply cannot afford to pay you, as their business is going slowly right now. To this day I have not seen even one AI product in production - and our smallest customer has around 10k employees worldwide. So if even they are not using AI in production - who is!?  ---------------------------------  One more comment: And don't forget the irony, that so many people claim AI will be taking developer jobs. If I knew how, I would automate half my work in home-office and simply be payed the same for less effort. But no, AI is so damn stupid that it is like a self-writing wikipedia, but barely anything more. Just today I was using AI for reading up on a specific python framework's documentation, and the AI gave me a stupid suggestion on which API to use for a specific use case. The example the AI (claude 4) gave me already contained another API method which could be used instead, and made everything else unnecessary. But - being a stupid AI - I had to tell the AI exactly that, after which it obviously responded with "blablabla you are totally correct blablabla". So even though as a product architect on this subject, I am also the leading dev. on everything AI, I still did not find any way to get the AI to write useful code for us. Because I essentially have to tell the AI everything I told students, when I was teaching at a German university over 10 years ago. It's frustrating and makes no sense to even try - just hire someone who knows these things, instead of trying to "educate" an AI every time you see it doing some nonsense BS. Because no static prompt you can give the bot, will actually make it stick to your rules, as it arbitrarily ignores them.   So no - AIs are not going to take any complex or engineering jobs. But it will take jobs/tasks related to art or entertainment. Because in these jobs failure is not hard, but "only" results in a less satisfying customer experience, instead of a total production or process failure.

The sad thing is a lot of my peers were told ‚Äújust do your schooling, and a job will be handed to you‚Äù this was not really the case ever, but it was easier to keep applying and the numbers eventually came in your favour. Nowadays, my peers had no connections, no work experience besides their degree and they graduated right when AI boomed and the economy went downhill. commentText: My go to: ask where they want you to be 1 week, 1 month, and before the end of the probationary period in terms of skill and independence. It 1. shows long term commitment and 2. makes them SEE YOU in that role. You've told them about your work history and made some basic rapport, now make them picture you in the role.   (I'm autistic and worked in HR. Most interviewers are zoned out at best, say something interesting or weirdly specific to make you stand out. I bring up projects that weren't company focused, but internally focused, making me seem more stable and long term. üëçüèΩ but also it is a tough job market even for the most qualified people... I know people with phds working part time right now)

commentText: I think a big part of why it‚Äôs not being talked about, is because a lot of people don‚Äôt see it as any different than the longstanding [it was already being parodied in _Office Space_ (1999) ] corporate trend of dumping employees in favor of contractors with no benefits. So this was already a huge problem, and the inclusion of foreign contractors in countries with significantly lower costs of living changes it, but doesn‚Äôt _dramatically_ change it. It‚Äôs an acceleration, not an inflection point.   Which doesn‚Äôt mean that it‚Äôs not bad or not worth talking about. And the acceleration can make a thing that was a minor problem around the edges into a society-undermining problem. But most humans are very bad at recognizing creeping threats, very bad at planning for nebulous threats, and bad-to-very-bad at cognitive empathy. So I think the lack of conversation reflects lack of recognizing that this is a systemic problem. Thanks for bringing it up!  But I also think this reflects factionalism and lack of much trans-national worker solidarity to counterbalance the power of transnational corporations. In the US, big transnational corporations and some politicians have for 50+ years mostly succeeded in scapegoating workers in lower-COL countries and pitting US workers against them. Most of the US unions completely fell for this in the 1970s-1990s, pushing to prevent offshoring of manufacturing jobs through contracts and legislation, instead of pushing to unionize the foreign workers. They saw foreign workers as unfair  competition instead of recognizing the corporations and shareholders as the source of the problem.

videoTitle: Why Jobs Are Disappearing In The U.S.
videoDescription: Relatively few people are finding new jobs in the United States. The slowdown in hiring comes as businesses navigate rapidly ...
commentText: Another serious consequence of rapid AI adoption is the disappearance of entry-level positions ‚Äî the very roles people rely on to gain experience and grow into more advanced careers.  In many industries, AI systems are now handling tasks that used to be done by junior employees or interns. This creates a paradox: companies require experience for mid- and senior-level roles, but the entry-level jobs where that experience is usually gained are no longer available. As a result, new graduates and career-switchers are left with no real pathway to break into the field.  This issue is especially pronounced in tech and creative sectors, where automation and generative AI can already perform a wide range of tasks that were once assigned to beginners. If people can‚Äôt get that first job, they can‚Äôt build a portfolio, learn on the job, or advance in their profession. It becomes a closed loop ‚Äî one that excludes the next generation of talent before they even have a chance to start.  Long-term, this not only hurts individuals, but weakens entire industries by cutting off the supply of fresh minds and future experts.

videoTitle: Why Jobs Are Disappearing In The U.S.
videoDescription: Relatively few people are finding new jobs in the United States. The slowdown in hiring comes as businesses navigate rapidly ...
commentText: Learn from  Your history:  The Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 did not work as intended because it led to a disastrous cycle of retaliatory tariffs from other countries. Rather than protecting American businesses, the act caused a sharp drop in international trade and deepened the economic hardships of the Great Depression.  Key reasons the Smoot-Hawley Tariff failed Sparked global trade wars In response to the U.S. raising tariffs on over 20,000 imported goods, foreign nations retaliated with their own tariffs on American products. Canada, the biggest U.S. trading partner at the time, was one of the first to respond with countermeasures. This cycle of "beggar-thy-neighbor" protectionism worsened the global economic crisis.  Caused international trade to plummet Between 1929 and 1934, global trade volumes shrank by approximately 65%. U.S. imports and exports to Europe fell by two-thirds from 1929 to 1932. The decline in exports was especially damaging to American farmers, who had already been struggling with overproduction and low prices.  Failed to help the U.S. economy The act's goal was to protect American industries and farmers, but the result was higher prices for American consumers at a time when purchasing power was already weak. The drop in exports contributed to bank failures and worsening unemployment, pushing the country deeper into the Depression.  Ignored warnings from economists More than 1,000 U.S. economists signed a petition urging President Herbert Hoover to veto the bill. However, Hoover signed the bill into law in June 1930, overriding the concerns of the experts.  Contributed to global political instability Beyond the immediate economic fallout, the Smoot-Hawley Act is seen by some historians as contributing to the rise of political extremism in other countries by destabilizing their economies.  Historical context and legacy The Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act did not cause the Great Depression, which was already underway, but it is widely considered a major policy misstep that exacerbated the crisis. The act is a classic cautionary tale in modern economics, highlighting the dangers of protectionist trade policies and the interconnectedness of the global economy.

videoDescription: Relatively few people are finding new jobs in the United States. The slowdown in hiring comes as businesses navigate rapidly ...
commentText: The same thing happened in Japan about 20 to 30 years ago. That generation is known as the ‚Äúemployment ice age‚Äù generation, and their incomes are clearly lower than those of other generations. Even though the population was large, many people in that cohort ended up in unstable or part-time jobs, which caused the birth rate to drop sharply and accelerated population decline.  Now the situation has gone too far in the opposite direction: because of the shrinking population, almost every workplace is suffering from labor shortages. People in their 20s and 30s are especially in high demand, and even those with no experience are trained closely and carefully.  Thirty years ago, companies were in a position to choose workers and often acted arrogantly. Today, it‚Äôs the other way around‚Äîyoung workers will simply say, ‚ÄúIf that‚Äôs the kind of company this is, goodbye,‚Äù and quit. As a result, companies have to be much more careful in how they train and treat employees.

videoTitle: Why Jobs Are Disappearing In The U.S.
videoDescription: Relatively few people are finding new jobs in the United States. The slowdown in hiring comes as businesses navigate rapidly ...
commentText: The rapid and widespread implementation of AI and automation in recent years has created a significant disruption in the global labor market. While these technologies were introduced under the promise of improving efficiency and reducing costs, the social and economic consequences have been largely underestimated ‚Äî or ignored altogether.  By replacing human labor at scale ‚Äî in everything from customer service to programming, logistics, and even creative work ‚Äî we've created a situation where millions of people are being pushed out of the workforce faster than new opportunities are being created. The result is not just higher unemployment, but also a shrinking consumer base. People without stable incomes cannot meaningfully participate in the economy, which undermines the very demand that companies rely on to sustain their operations.  Automation has certainly increased productivity in many sectors, but that increase has not translated into broad-based prosperity. Instead, it has concentrated profits in fewer hands while leaving large portions of the population economically insecure. This isn't just a technological issue ‚Äî it's a systemic one, where economic structures are not adapting fast enough to absorb the social impact of automation.  Without a balanced approach ‚Äî one that includes thoughtful regulation, reskilling programs, and policies that ensure people can still afford to live and participate in society ‚Äî we risk creating a cycle where efficiency gains actually weaken the economy rather than strengthen it.  AI and automation are powerful tools, but without a long-term vision and human-centered planning, they can do more harm than good.

videoTitle: WTF Is Happening To The Job Market
videoDescription: Something is seriously wrong with the job market and it's about to get worse. The modern job search has become a frustrating and ...
commentText: The housing collapse was the first crack. Banks gambled, collapsed, and got taxpayer bailouts. Executives handed themselves bonuses with public money while the public paid the price. Occupy Wall Street tried to push back, but nothing truly changed. The same players stayed in power. The rules stayed rigged.  Now we are living through the next phase. Mass layoffs, ghost jobs, AI filters, and stagnant wages are everywhere. Profits soar, shareholders celebrate, and executives cash out while telling workers to be grateful for scraps.  Meritocracy is gone. Optics replaced it. Corporate success is no longer built on value or skill, but on who can perform the best image while cutting the people they parade for PR. Behind the curtain, the human element is gone, and the fa√ßade grows thicker.  AI is not the enemy. The real danger is AI CEOs and executives who treat technology as their personal crown. They are not building; they are competing to out-narcissist each other, blinded by ego and greed. Investors fuel this arms race because it spikes their portfolios, no matter the long-term damage. Behind closed doors, the C-suite and shareholders pat themselves on the back while carving out what remains of the middle class.  This is not about politics. It is about power. The ultra-wealthy control the levers and have no interest in building a system that works for anyone else. This is the second reckoning. The first was the manufacturing carve-out that gutted entire communities. This one is a technological carve-out, and its effects are already eroding the workforce from within.  If you feel invisible, you are not imagining it. This market is not broken; it is built to extract and discard. Until people stop accepting optics for progress and demand substance, the machine will keep grinding through generation after generation.  The ultra-wealthy will not save us. They are too busy competing to see who can burn it down the fastest.

commentText: I closed my laptop two minutes into an interview. Posted as remote, anywhere in my province. The interviewer asked how my day was going so far, I said something about the weather in my city that day. They froze, then said something about needing to be onsite (which was 4hrs away) once a week. I reminded her the posting only indicated remote work and she apologized for it being incorrect. I mentioned that I had another application pending for the same org, and wondered if she knew anything about the status of it. When I told her the position title, she told me it was a duplicate posting just worded slightly different. I told her there was a $35k difference between the two job listings. She froze again and I left the call shaking my head. That was one of only five interviews I got out of 70+ applications in a year.

commentText: I drove 45 minutes and showed up to a job interview and told the people at the front desk that I was here for an interview.  They looked confused and asked me for the name of the person I was supposed to be interviewing.  I gave them the name.  A little bit later, that person came out and we went into a private room to start talking.  They told me that the job was "recently filled" and there wasn't anything currently open anymore, but that they liked my resume enough that they wanted to talk to me in-person for "potential future opportunities".  At this point, I was seething so hard, I wanted to yell at them for wasting my time or say something snarky to this hiring manager.  But I practiced self control and played along and did my best as if the job was open, all the while rage was boiling in my stomach;  I didn't want to burn any bridges in-case this company is my last resort down the line and they do have something open in the far future.    But what a waste of my time, my whole day was wasted on this that could have been spent searching/applying for more jobs or preparing for a real interview.

But now the entire process of getting one of those jobs is sounding less and less appealing, let alone realistic. I work at a public library in my hometown and never had to worry about competing with hundreds of other candidates, getting ghosted by the company, or getting interviewed by AI. The person I emailed my resume to is the same person who interviewed me and who is now my boss. I used to think we were at a disadvantage living in a smaller place, with fewer opportunities, but now I see we are actually so lucky to have a job market with real people and real jobs.

commentText: Hearing to tailor the resume for each job posting, on top of already tailoring the cover letter for each job post, sounds fine in a small scale. But is unbelievably exhausting in reality. A lot of us applying to hundreds of jobs are doing that. It feels like it's just a pure numbers game rather than anything else. No matter how perfect a resume, cover letter, skills/abilities you have, experience history, etc., none of that seems to matter in the grand scheme of things. It's either you know someone, are able to know someone (and they're also willing to give you the time of day, which many aren't), or you have the willpower and patience to send out an infinite number of applications just for the hope of hearing back from a small few. Sorry if this sounds defeatist, I do appreciate the discussion and the advice, but this just eats away at you to where you just don't feel human anymore.

commentText: What is wrong with the job market? We‚Äôre in a government policy induced economic crash. The federal government has purposefully crashed the economy to forestall entitlement reforms, tax reform, immigration reform, and industrial policy reform. Any reforms would risk uprooting entrenched financial positions so they‚Äôre crashing the economy instead. AI should be a boon for productivity but that can only happen during economic growth periods. So that‚Äôs why the AI is fundamentally useless. AI allows people to do more work to less knowledge, but when the government increases inflation by printing money while simultaneously making it more and more expensive to hire and import, we get an economic crash instead of an uptick in quality of life. By the end of 2028 there will be a full blown economic depression similar to 2008, or perhaps even worse.

commentText: Tampa is indeed the city, however, we call the metro/surrounding areas (counties) ‚Äúthe Tampa Bay Area‚Äù. Also, people are leaving here in droves. We got hit with two back to back hurricanes last year that were horrendous (Helene and Milton). Lots of flooding in Tampa and surrounding counties. People can‚Äôt afford the insane property taxes and insurance rates, that‚Äôs assuming you can even get insured. Homes are no longer ‚Äúcheap‚Äù and rents are sky high. Car insurance is some of the highest in the country. The main issue with Florida is that we are up there in the top costliest states to live in yet, the salaries here are amongst the worst. The COL is insane compared to the salaries. If all of that sounds good, plus, hurricanes, tornadoes, lightning that kills every year, crazy traffic, overcrowding, extreme heat/humidity for most of the year, no seasonal changes, tense political climate, bugs, gators, venomous everything, etc‚Ä¶I could go on‚Ä¶then yes, by all means, move to Tampa üòÇ Signed- someone who‚Äôs unfortunately lived here for over 40 years.

commentText: The wife and I went to St. George Utah 21 years ago and said we were going to move there when we retired.  We ended up somewhere else but St. George still calls me.  BTW, Mesquite, NV is a great place.  We went there at the same time we checked out St. George, and the (literal) local newspaper headline said 'GRAFFITI IN MESQUITIE".  That was due to someone writing graffiti on one of the high schools' walls, they had the picture and everything.  Mesquite also ahd a large $$ surplus when we visited, all of the people from Utah drove over the border and gambled enough to keep Mesquite doing very nicely, at least back then.  How many places have budget surpluses today?  That was 21 years ago and the place was beautiful and perfect for retirement, we just couldn't 'afford to retire while we were still in diapers.

commentText: I live in Lubbock, originally from New Mexico. I do and don't like it here. 1. The weather sucks. Summers are usually miserably hot, the wind and dust storms are horrible. I've never seen a tornado, but hail is likely to cause very expensive damage. It's flat and not that attractive. Some years its mostly green but it's usually brown and dead looking from a lack of water. The pay in Lubbock is horribly low. On the upside, housing is lower than most places, though not as low as it once was and no longer low enough to justify the abysmal wages. But the worst is the lack of public land that I'm used to in New Mexico. No public hiking, camping, hunting, ect. There is nothing to do here unless you are wealthy and if you are you usually travel elsewhere, like New Mexico or Colorado. Oh and the sales tax? 8.25% is abusive. I frequently make high dollar purchases in New Mexico to pay a lower sales tax. (screw you tx).

commentText: The snowfall wasn't what caused the power outage in 2021. It was the temperatures getting down into the single digits for multiple days. Colder areas are better prepared for this, but in Texas most people have either natural gas or electric heating, primarily heat pumps. The problem with heat pumps, and why they're not relied on heavily in colder areas, is that they're only effective down to about 20¬∫F. Below that, they switch into "emergency heating" which is a form of resistance heating and only about 20-25% as efficient as a heat pump. So the grid saw a massive spike in energy usage in a small timeframe. Something that doesn't happen in colder areas where people would never consider using electrical resistance heating as it's too expensive.

commentText: Tornadoes are most common in the central and eastern United States, an area known as "Tornado Alley," which includes states like Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas, and Nebraska. However, activity has been shifting east, making the southeastern U.S. ("Dixie Alley") and parts of the Midwest, such as Colorado and Illinois, increasingly prone to tornadoes. Globally, North America experiences the most tornadoes, with Bangladesh, Argentina, and Australia also having regions with high activity.

commentText: It‚Äôs honestly gotten to the point that I have fully abandoned the job boards when submitting applications. I will look up companies I want to work for and apply directly, and sometimes, the many reason I have it. I will find jobs on indeed, then go to their websites to see if the job is posted there. commentText: Ive lived in CT my whole life, and when i was 20 i worked at a gas stationas an assistant manager. One day my boss put a hiring sign in the front window and i asked her how many people we were loking to hire. She told me zero. Appsrently around 2010 CT created a law stating that all companies had to advertise that they were hiring. Part of that law was that no one could be denied an application if the store used paper ones, if not you had to explain to the person how to apply online. It was supposedly meant to help decrease all types of prejudice during the hiring process. It made no sense to me because if a manager was prejudice, that persn they didnt like would never make it past the first interview. Anyways, all it did was fool people into thinking we were actually hiring when we werent. It wasted everyone involved time. I tried explaining the law to people when they would come back in or call about the application they dropped off weeks ago. People were pissed. I was mad because i had to keep dealing with everyone who was upset.

commentText: Part of it, I believe I've heard, is to make it look like they are hiring, even getting applications, so when an employee asks for a raise, they can point to the listings only to say that they have hundreds of people looking to get the employee's job. That they should be grateful for what they have and that they can replace them on a whim. Sure, they possibly could, however, that doesn't account for training, the risk of a new hire possibly not fitting in or being even more of a pain to work with, and they already have as few people hired as possible, so they don't want to fire you, because even if they get a replacement, that's a role that's not going to be functioning properly, if at all for a while when you're gone. But they can always threaten you and make you feel replaceable so you don't ask for a raise, or potentially even take a pay cut.  Manipulation is standard practice in a capitalist system.

commentText: If you are applying for jobs you should expect 9 out of 10 jobs to be ghost jobs or required postings. If the job has little more then a title, likely a ghost job. If the posting has a very eclectic mix of requirements likely a required post tailored to the person pre-selected to fill it. If a generally cohesive wish list with few requirements, that likely a real job. General 10-20 applications per interview and 10-20 interviews to get hired. I have successfully done this 3 times, once for an entry level job and twice for student level jobs. All the other jobs used industry contacts, recruiters, and general back channel shenanigans. If you are not networking it's almost impossible to get employed üòï And at some point when you get higher in your career they don't post jobs or even have them. It is more about having a contact in a company that is growing and can create a position for you. But that's VP level positions and while I have had spots created for me it is not common at my level and some of that may have, honestly, been DEI opportunity for the company.

commentText: Austin‚Äôs growth cooling off isn‚Äôt just about housing prices or traffic, it‚Äôs also because of the whole ‚Äúreturn to office‚Äù push. During the pandemic, tons of people bailed on places like NYC, LA, San Francisco, Seattle, and Chicago and set up shop in cities and places like Austin, Charlotte, Nashville, etc. since they were cheaper, but now companies are cracking down. Charles Schwab is mandating people come back four days a week starting in March 2026, T. Rowe Price announced basically the same thing just weeks earlier, and JP Morgan straight-up told employees they‚Äôve got a year to move back to be in office or find a new job. So for a lot of folks who moved to places like Austin and others, it‚Äôs a brutal choice, either pack up again to keep their career or stay put and hope they can land something local that actually compares. That wave of workers who gave Austin and others its big boom just don‚Äôt have the same freedom anymore, and it‚Äôs showing in the slowdown.

commentText: As a former Uber driver in Austin I have seen a huge difference in my city in the last 2 or 3 years. The Dirty Six, Rainy Street and West Sixth Street were always packed with young people and tourists. I mean 7 days a week! Young tech professionals flocked here in droves. The restaurants and hotels were packed all the time. Driving Uber here was unbelievable! I made so much money and it was fun being around all of these positive smart young people.   These kids didn‚Äôt care about politics, high cost of rent or the 4 months of very hot weather. They loved it here!   Here‚Äôs what I think happened‚Ä¶.. first of all, the convention center is closed for renovations and won‚Äôt open back up for a few years. That‚Äôs thousands of business people every day that aren‚Äôt here.   As for the young people that moved here. They started missing their family back home. That‚Äôs pretty natural. The bar scene has either gotten scetchy or they‚Äôre just gone. Most of the Rainy Street bars have been replaced with condos. The dirty six is very sketchy and abandoned. West Sixth Street and the East side are hanging in there. Yes, cost of living and the hot summers aren‚Äôt for everyone, but that didn‚Äôt seem to bother people a few years ago.   Well, that‚Äôs my opinion. I hope it helps.

commentText: As a minority with two children currently in AISD, I could say some critical things about Austin, but none of what you might expect.  My daughter‚Äôs public school leans heavily toward the ‚Äúeveryone is a protected class‚Äù end of the social spectrum, but the education she is getting there is twice as strong as what she received at her previous school. My son‚Äôs high school, also in AISD, is ranked 36th in the entire country. Just yesterday he showed me a homework assignment where he was analyzing translated Arabic texts for clues about the influence of technology on ancient medical practices, not Bible verses or tales from the Alamo (nothing wrong with those).  In short, we braced for the worst and found the best. Austin has its problems, but it is an amazing city for families and for people who love the outdoors. I run Mount Bonnell and the Town Lake trails year-round and it is fantastic. That is what sweat is for and after 2 weeks of running you don't notice it.   And the music? Incredible. Last night I saw Mdou Moctar, a psychedelic African rock band, along with The Point, a local Austin band. My mind was blown, I was home by 10, and back at work by 8 a.m. That is just a normal Thursday night here. The city is overflowing with options and opportunities. I have taken an art class at ACC on ancient Turkish ebru techniques, and last month I went to a free lecture at UT on quantum physics followed by drinks with people from the AT&T Center. And do not even get me started on the food.

commentText: Austin was never meant to be a big major city in the first place. Both the city and its suburbs are not equipped infrastructure wise to be a major metropolitan area and they were always struggling to catch up with the uncontrollable rapid growth and development. Plus the city itself was more suburban and tacky in character and lacked the urban cityscapes and diversity. Austin was only meant to be a small to medium sized government town just like Little Rock, Baton Rouge, and Montgomery with a modest sized metropolitan area. Austin and its suburbs are now paying the heavy negative price of trying to be like San Antonio, Fort Worth, Dallas, and Houston when they should have remained a government and university town. Austin and its metro area need to shrink greatly in population and return to what it originally was back in the 60s and 70s.

commentText: Husband and I live between San Antonio and Austin.  About 3 years ago we took my daughter to catch a late flight out of the airport in Austin.  Decided to stop by a famous doughnut shop in the downtown area on the way home. I could not believe the decline I saw from previous visits.  Downtown was trashy, full of drunks and homeless.  Police were trying to deal with traffic, nuts and drunks.  When parking in front of the doughnut shop a person would not move out of the way for me to open my car door.  The rudeness from those that night we came in contact with did not reflect the usual friendly attitude most Texans are known for. Have not been back since, except to go to the airport.  Also the nightmare of freeway construction never ends.  Miles of freeway 35 has been a death trap.  Toll roads are only used by those who can afford them and have light traffic on them.  If the tolls were suspended at least until the construction is over with, it would make commuting easier for everyone else by easing the traffic.  In fact the tolls need to be done away with!  We pay our gas taxes. That is another story; how the funds for roads had been diverted to other state government spending.

commentText: For decades, one of the perks of the State Fair for Texas was free admission for the surrounding school districts. This year for the first time, they are no longer blessing school children with free admission. Parents didn‚Äôt mind spending money on parking, food, rides, and games when their  children had free admissions. Now that the entire family has to pay to enter the fairgrounds, lots of them are enjoying Six Flags Over Texas. This past weekend, my grandson‚Äòs school choir had a field trip to Six Flags, and it was very crowded.   If the State Fair wants to survive this season, they need to allow free access to school age children.

commentText: I live in St Petersburg Florida, which has seen unprecedented migration from all over the country. It went from being a sleepy little town to a packed metropolis. Despite that, at the same time every business is closing, cutting hours or laying people off. A Wendy's just closed, a Checkers just closed. Village Inn cut hours, IHOP cut hours. The local ice cream shop that's been around since the 60s closed, the local burger place that's been open since the 60s closed. Home Shopping Network closed. For the first time since the 1970s we don't have a 24-hour or even late night grocery store. I know people with multiple college degrees who have been looking for a job for the past 6 months with no luck. There are homeless people everywhere. When I do ride sharing I take people with full-time jobs home to efficiency apartments, trailer parks and motel rooms.  The average studio apartment is over $2,000. I'm pretty sure that there's a crash coming any moment now.

commentText: Hey Michael, here's my opinion on unemployment rate: Its an acute figure that only reflects recently laid off workers within the past 2-3 months at a given point in time.  In reality it is much, much, worse.  Basically, the unemployment pipeline is: Get laid off without any cause provided, the state gives you unemployment benefit.   Apply for thousands of fake indeed  tax-write-off listing jobs per week to document in order to receive said benefit.  After 3 months of not hearing back from anyone your unemployment benefit runs out.  Either give up or doordash, either way, the government no longer considers you unemployed.

commentText: It's good to have multiple trade skills like plumbing, electrician, HVAC, roofer, framer, painter, landscaping, road paver, machanic, nursing, etc. That way you can pivot to the jobs that are in demand when your job goes away. My mistake was I didn't invest in myself and didn't learn multiple skills until I was laid off this year. Right now I am learning to be an electrician and it's going to take another 8 months to finish. I would recommend to anyone that is employed at a single job, go and get certified in other fields while you have the opportunity. It will be less stressful than when you have to work minimum wage job, do a side hustle, and learn a new skill.

commentText: The economy is suffering due to poor fundamentals.  These include the overall phenomenon called "structural unemployment."  Some economists have predicted this for decades because of its Malthusian essence.  Too many people, not enough jobs.  It will never return to what was.  It's not part of normal economic cycles that the experts are so fond of citing. It's exacerbated by AI and robotics.  Unless the government was proactive in planning to make society more socialistic, and improving conditions for citizens, then it's a down hill slide towards a plutocracy. Unfortunately that's the widening chasm between the rich and the poor, leaving the mid-class in tatters trying to maintain their standard of living in a country where the average person is involved in a non-consensual relationship with an economy hell bent on fleecing the shit out of people.  The automobile is the biggest fraud ever perpetrated on a populace. Just add up all the costs inherent in the operation of your car and hang up and drive.  The fender bender industry wants you on your phone, with headlights unique to each model and absurd prices for injection molded parts with insane margins. Back to the acyclic economic milieu in which we exist.  The end of the petroleum age means that we are seeing prices rise based on a truer calculation of embedded costs.   The slow death of urban core retail means that commercial real estate is getting shitty, and that sector has anchored funds and such for years.   Bankers are slow to adjust. Every company is squeezing everything for revenue, meaning the firings and the terrible job market are the tip of the iceberg. The guy who got voted in isn't doing anything to help you folks that believed the rhetoric.  He just wants to aggrandize himself and his cronies by reviving the polluting of our country while bad mouthing renewable energy because of its effect on the "landscape."   Since when has he given a shit about the natural world? Has he visited an open pit mine recently.  He has doubled his net worth over the last 6-18 months, while most US citizens are suffering.   Make no mistake: He doesn't give a shit about any of us, unless you're part of the war machine dominated by the Big 5 and go to Davos or Tetons.   Over Easter he dismissed us all and said "just enjoy your life" in a display of such callous indifference the average person's plight as to be obscene. He has begun to take away the basic right to free speech and his attacks on people smarter than he is who criticize what is happening is truly frightening.  We should all be very concerned and petition our generally greedy representatives who are often focused on their own inside information making their assisted stock market picks way easier. Stop attacking people who you might call liberal and understand that it will require all of us to find accord and quorum to achieve any progress.   Infighting and factionalism will be our downfall.

commentText: During the pandemic, most tech companies experienced record profits while commercial real estate firms incurred losses. When the pandemic restrictions lifted, commercial real estate companies were finally able to raise rents to recover their losses. Simultaneously, many tech firms sought to exit their 10-year office leases as remote work allowed them to save significantly on expenses. Unfortunately, the commercial real estate companies won several court cases, leaving tech firms burdened with rising rents for vacant office spaces. This situation prompted mass layoffs and enforced return-to-office mandates. Executives at leading tech companies were unwilling to accept a minor pay cut to retain their workforce. Instead, they prioritized short-term profits over the wellbeing of their employees.

commentText: Very sobering but good realistic take on this. Sometimes I regret having not figured out tech was the right career choice before the mass layoffs / shift started, but I forget that a lot of companies did over-hire in the period prior to this, so it might not have necessarily led to long-term security, even after getting a foot in the door. I guess the only way to ensure that is to develop your expertise and have a good overall career strategy, along with some good fortune - even if the climate is tough.  I'm also a bit jaded by the concept of companies as 'families', which has never really been true - that's usually to get your buy-in but without the reciprocal part of actual families which is that you don't chuck your family members under the bus to save yourself or make more profit. It's disappointing that DEI is collateral in this as well, which as you say highlights that it often wasn't an actual core value but rather a flimsy policy that follows the market/administration at the time. You'd hope that the right companies hold values (whatever our view of them) for their own intrinsic merit, but often that's not the case.

commentText: The problem is oversupply.  There are too many pharmacists. There are too many lawyers. Those two professions require state licensure and those will get fixed over time when lifetime student loan limits are reduced to $50k for undergrad, $100k for grad, $150k for professional school, and $200k for overall student debt including Parent PLUS. PSLF won't be a thing much longer. Unfortunately, that won't happen with software engineering because you don't need a CS degree or a state license so the oversupply will continue. And on top of that, there is this tool called AI that's already good enough to replace 0.5 junior FTE when the AI tool is put in the hands of a competent senior FTE.  AI will probably reduce the need for lawyers too. I can see the day when I can update my trust with AI instead of a lawyer. I guess I should take an antidepressant lol.

Previously, if there was even a minor typo or minor mistake, sometimes it would take 2 hours or more to find out errors. Simple task like this and even crafting code for a function etc would bring smile to face after it worked ( the thinking part ). Now such silly mistake are caught by AI prompt instantly, Every function code can be written and refactored by AI. Software engineering has move a whole level up, the lower level where most of the thinking and 'writing code' used to be is no longer there. As a result, Client/team-lead now expect us to churn out 1000s of lines of AI assisted code and churn out features at the rate, when previously every feature used to be a journey in itself with learned ( or googled ) code and puzzle solving. As a result, the whole 'coding' part of software engineering ( atleast 90% anyway ) no longer feels like  a challenging job and thinking is relegated to AI. Most software engineer are now relagated to 'software prompter'.

I wasn't even that offended honestly I just thought oof... how cooked are we software engineering brothers and sisters?    I still love the actual act of computer programming but I can't let it define me too much especially with our field being wrecked by AI/offshoring/bottom feeders.  This is the second time my career field has gotten wrecked in this way, I was in film and television before and I thought I left it to get away from this kind of shit but it followed me I guess.    "You are not your job" from Fight Club is about to become more relevant than ever as AI and automation lays waste to 90% of blue and white collar jobs alike. videoTitle: Why software engineering is no longer a dream job
videoDescription: To try everything Brilliant has to offer‚Äîfree‚Äîfor a full 30 days, visit https://brilliant.org/CatherineLi You will get 20% off Brilliant's ...
commentText: It is because the industry is saturated with too many folks claiming to "engineers" because they know how to code in java script or python or multiple frameworks based on them.    And those things are nowhere near what defined a software engineer 40 years ago, not just because of the change in languages being used, but the breadth of knowledge that was part of the definition.   The technical definition of software engineer is someone who understands how to create software to implement solutions to problems on various types of systems.  That is far more than knowing a programming language.     All of this happened because web programming took off and there was a need for a large number of developers to create web applications.  And as the evolution of web programming technologies took place with the development of new languages, protocols, mobile devices and frameworks, the need for large numbers of programmers stayed high to handle the transition to new ways of doing things.     But all of this forced a more specialized definition of software development in education that is often focused on more on what is current and trendy vs the basics of software and engineering.   And now, most programming is not super complex and involves knowledge of html, java script and some combination of frameworks and certainly doesn't justify huge salaries to go along with it.   So as the economy has changed and easy money dried up due to rising interest rates, corporations have had to trim the fat.   Not to mention all the money is in AI now, so unless you are doing anything related to AI, the money isn't really flowing in.  On top of that you have a "global market" now for employment with people all over the world competing for the same jobs, which the industry also wants to have access to for their ideas to potentially profit from.  And of course, many of those developers are cheaper than those in the US.   So it is easier to justify hiring offshore programmers to do commodity web applications as you aren't really doing anything super sophisticated in the first place vs pretending those apps need high paid "software engineers" to build and maintain.

commentText: Automation and robotics will necessarily replace human workers because of how the current economic system works. Companies that automate lower their costs and become more competitive. Those that keep higher-cost human labor fall behind and will go out of business. This creates a system where replacing people with machines is not just likely, but necessary for company survival. There is a way around this, but it would require a full revamp of the social contract and our concept of work. Even capitalists will want this change when unemployment reaches a tipping point and there‚Äôs no one left with money to buy the products they‚Äôre selling.

commentText: The pandemic wiped out my job in the travel industry. Little by little, my working hours shrunk until I could no longer support myself, even with unemployment assistance supplementing my meager earnings. Fortunately, I have a degree, and a kind neighbor got me hired with her company. I was 63 years old and had NEVER used Zoom. I had 2 Zoom interviews with the company and got hired with full benefits. I realize that I possessed great privilege to be able to do that at my age. Now I'm retired and feel so bad for professionals who are highly qualified, educated, and unable to get interviews. I feel bad for employees working multiple jobs and barely making it. This corrupt society is so unfair to honest people. .

commentText: And people wondering why college graduates can't make rent:  4-year Bachelor's graduates: Make $1100 a month National rent average: $1900 a month Food cost: $400 per month per person Utilities: Roughly $800-1200 per month, not including internet service Phone bill: $100 per month, minimum Car payment: $200 per month lease Fuel: @$3.00 per gallon, 15-gallon gas tank, 300 miles per tank: $180 per month, more if you get stuck in city "stop-and-go" traffic  Add it all up, and the following becomes true.  In 1980, you could buy a house ($47,000) on a minimum wage ($3.10 per hour). Rent was an average of $243 per month. Groceries was $40 a week/$160 per month.  In 2025, the cost to buy a house is 9.8 times what it was in 1980, at a national average of $417,000. Yet minimum wage is only $7.25 an hour, up from $3.10 per hour. It used to be $80,000 per year was considered middle class; now middle class is $185,000.  Point is, the old thinking is for an old age. The Industral Age has given way to the Information Age, and no longer do the old ways work, simply because the old ways has put way too many people in a hole they will never get out of.  Minimum yearly salary is not $35,000 anymore, for even entry-level. My guess is that minimum yearly salary should be around $50,000 per year.  And companies need to stop passing the buck on costs to consumers, who are already paying way too much as it is.

videoTitle: Americans Are FURIOUS At The INSANE Job Market
videoDescription: TikTok: https://www.tiktok.com/@jayyreed?_t=ZP-8xpYGIP7xPD&_r=1 Equipment I use in my videos: Swinging pendulum ...
commentText: We have no idea what this job is, or how many hours a week.  Assuming 40 hours, doing the math it comes to $16.75 per hour (assuming US).  That is apparently starting pay.  When I started working at 18 I made $3.85 an hour (in 1972; minimum wage was $1.60.).  I had multiple roommates; I paid $50 per month for a bed in an old farmhouse with no heat.  (In LA, so not so bad, but still...)  After five years my pay had more than doubled.  After seven years I had been promoted to a skilled craft job.  Five more years and I was promoted to "Engineering Assistant."  Four more years and they made me a Supervisor within my work group.  A decade more and the moved me into Engineering, making me a Senior Engineer a year later, and eventually a Lead Network Engineer.  The point being, does this job have a future, or is it a dead end?  That makes a huge difference in whether to accept the job or not.  (Besides the basic, "How much do I need some kind of job right now?)  These are the sorts of real-world considerations these superficial skits ignore.

videoTitle: The Brutal Reality of the Tech Job Market
videoDescription: The tech job market right now is brutal. Layoffs, endless applications, and constant rejections. It feels impossible to land an offer.
commentText: I've come to the conclusion that I no longer want to chase after a language or framework. This changes all the time. I've also decided that I will no longer subject myself to being treated like a commodity at a cattle auction. In the end, all of this is designed to make you accept doing more for less. I think at some point we give in and accept unrealistic things because the "market demands it," or the influencer you follow or the group of followers in the bubble you're in dictates that this is the culture, technology, or method to be adopted. Yes, I went through a financial setback and had to accept working in other segments. But that didn't kill my desire to work with software. Today, I think the path is to work as an entrepreneur and consultant for small businesses, creating solutions for the region you live in or where you can work without creating a burden on your life. Another mistake I see is the industrialization of the IT workforce. We didn't start that way; we started in a garage or on a small project; we're not cattle.

commentText: I worked in tech for 45 years in several roles. When I started, ‚ÄúBeing in computers.‚Äù, was like saying you were a Wizard in a tower. Your job was mysterious and magical and few others were in the industry competing for these enchanted positions. I retired a few years ago.  Nowadays, computer techs are a commodity and the perception is of an office worker. You are disposable and can be replaced in days from thousands of other candidates in your field. You‚Äôre no more important than a file clerk.  I worked through the tech industry‚Äôs best years and retired (age 60) at the tail end of that time.  Best of luck but it‚Äôs going to be a crap shoot and the jobs are pretty harsh.

videoTitle: The Brutal Reality of the Tech Job Market
videoDescription: The tech job market right now is brutal. Layoffs, endless applications, and constant rejections. It feels impossible to land an offer.
commentText: I'm sorry the market is so brutal.  I would suggest, in the meantime, code your own apps for sale in the app store.  Doing this will achieve a few powerful things: (1) keep your skills fresh, (2) create something to show off, (3) potentially make some good money on the sale of your apps, and (4) keep your mind sharp, fresh.  You can also use this time to achieve certifications.  At the end of the day, give major consideration in the idea of working for yourself, building your own solutions.

videoTitle: The Brutal Reality of the Tech Job Market
videoDescription: The tech job market right now is brutal. Layoffs, endless applications, and constant rejections. It feels impossible to land an offer.
commentText: The tech market isn't cooked, SWE jobs are cooked.  Lots of people don't realize there's so many other technical jobs out there to apply for. Look into Solution Engineer/Solutions Consultant roles, or Implementation Consultant, or Integration Specialist.  I went the implementation Consultant route, my current role only had 100 applicants in 2 weeks, meanwhile SWE jobs get 1000 applicants in 2 days.  I know it's easy to feel doomed but there are sooo many paths out there guys. I wouldn't even be surprised if I find myself as a SWE one day.

commentText: My son is a software developer.  He got an Associates degree from a community college, no debt.  He then went and learned about AS400's.  It's a niche and ancient lore.  But there are many companies still using it and all the skilled people retired a decade ago.  This got him into a couple of companies who needed that skill, where he learned a lot more.  He's now making mint, saved a bunch of cash, and is learning SAP development and has a government security clearance.  All these little things differentiate him.

commentText: Similar to 2008 housing crash where beginning in 2005  more and more houses came on market. Eventhough the biggest reason for the 2008 crash was years of easy mortgage qualifications, which lead up to people not being able to pay their mortgages. This time it may not be for the same reasons of more houses on the market, but rising # of houses on market is a clear indicator that we could be heading for another crash. Its still because people are finding it harder to pay their mortgages but for other factors: higher mortgage costs due to several years of higher interest , higher property taxes,.higher insurance costs ( due to more flooding, fires.etc), over abundance of investor companies buying up homes, home price increases due to pandemic, loss of jobs, less people being able to  buy 2nd homes and slowdown in people being able to afford as many if any vacations. All in all people are paying way over their means for housing. Home ownership costs are too high. A correction is coming and possibly a crash.

commentText: Very good analysis.  I live in northern Collin County (Near the Grayson County line).  I moved here in 2020.  What was once a 40 minute commute to Dallas is now well over 1 hour 15 minutes. (I'm retired so I have no commute but I do think some of my neighbors regret moving here)  New home construction here is still going on but noticeably much slower (even with crazy incentives).  I'm seeing neighbors pack up and leave.  I'm seeing others trying to sell.  They are stuck.  I monitor the foreclosures in my area and there are at least five homes a week in the last six months!  Personally, my home value has been relatively stable up slightly.  A re-correction was inevitable especially in areas like Austin and San Antonio.

commentText: I have thought for some time that the suburbs between Dallas and Fort Worth and some to the southern parts of the DFW area were underrated. They may not be as flashy and new (however, it wasn't that long ago that they were) or as out in the hinterlands as recent developments, but they do provide an opportunity for building higher density, and cheaper, housing away from the cores of either Dallas or Fort Worth. It's a different focus for a new 21st century world concerned with climate change and creating housing affordable for those seeking an urbanized suburban experience without the higher levels of traffic and congestion. They could also provide opportunities for retrofitting older homes and subdivisions with carbon neutral infrastructure. We live in Texas, but maybe, just maybe we could be among the first to face the music that bigger is not necessarily better.

commentText: The past 15-20 years have been hard getting a job in Texas. I was laid off in 2009. I had years of experience in int'l sales, purchasing and finance. I spoke 5 languages, 6 counting English. But I couldn't even find a job as a receptionist or file clerk. I just wanted to work. I looked for 2 years before my husband told me to stop. He told me to just handle the money; he had a secure job and made decent money. So, I did that, and I think I did it well. He retired early. We owe nothing and pay off every CC statement on receipt. I see all these people here looking for a job. I feel bad for them. I don't see a light at the end of the tunnel. Wish I could dynamite a hole for them.

commentText: The job market is collapsing in part because, just as the manufacturing industry was eventually outsourced to countries like China, office jobs‚Äîwhich were once considered safe‚Äîcan now also be outsourced due to advancements in technology and the internet. As a result, not only has manufacturing moved abroad, but traditional office jobs as well, further reducing the number of available jobs. Since wages in America are much higher compared to other countries, business owners face a choice: outsource or lose to the competition.

commentText: Senior full stack engineer here: That AI generated increase in productivity brings with it an equal increase in burnout at no additional benefit to me, the employee. The company just sees this as extra $$$ with less people doing the work. Why are we so obsessed with doing more when it doesn‚Äôt translate to more money in our pocket or free time?

videoTitle: My Honest Thoughts on the Software Engineering Job Market in 2025
videoDescription: Apply to see if you'd be a good fit for my mentorship program DevLaunch ...
commentText: The problem is YouTube is full of videos promising people financial freedom by simply learning how to talk to AI.    It doesn't help when top tech leaders are also saying the days of software development by human is over.   These tech leaders also do not understand the details because they don't do the work themselves either.   They only get to talk big in big events.  I am an experienced AI developer.   I tried my best several times to vibe code a complete product.   I failed in every single one of the experiment.   In all cases,  I get to 80% but that 20% will take forever and lots of frustration.   After that going into the code to fix it myself took longer than I would by developing them myself.   The only way that work for me is to use AI as my assistant.  I will have to do all the thinking and architecting.  I will translate the thinking into very specific instructions for AI to follow.   Only by doing that,  I could complete a project with productivity gain.

commentText: hey Tim in canada, this is Tim in canada. vibe coding seems to work to some degree like summarizing. i have found summarizing a whole book  with ollama and one of the latest models, gemma3, phi4, qwen to not be ideal. so what i do now is just summarize a chapter at a time. i find vibe coding to be similar. if i try to build more than a toy program with vibe coding it gets confused, halucinates, executes on features i dont want,  or just skips things i do want, or uses libraries i dont want used. so lately my approach is to just vibe code on specific features one at a time and test for each use case and assemble the pieces later. my results seem to be more dialed in like my results summarizing chapters instead of whole books.

commentText: I‚Äôve been working as a Data Engineer for 3 years now and hold a master‚Äôs degree. I‚Äôm currently at Huawei, and I‚Äôve recently been thinking deeply about where to focus next for my self-development. It's meaningful to me because I actually started learning to code with you 4 years ago‚Äîso thank you for being part of that journey.  I strongly agree with the idea that we should prioritize fundamentals rather than chasing every new AI update. However, I can‚Äôt ignore how rapidly things have changed. Just 3 years ago, there were no AI tools that could write code for us. Back then, knowing Python and SQL was enough to land my first job. Today, those same tasks can often be handled by AI.  That said, AI still struggles with areas like system design, architecture, performance optimization, and understanding the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind production decisions. But I can‚Äôt help but wonder‚Äîwhat if AI catches up in these areas too, just like it did with simple coding? It‚Äôs possible, maybe even likely, within the next couple of years.

videoTitle: The U.S. Recession is finally here.
videoDescription: ADP just released a shocking job market report, showing that employers shed 32000 jobs in September, signaling that we are ...
commentText: A trifecta of labor market readings just hit‚Äîand they all suggest a recession may already be underway:  ADP: 32,000 job losses in September  Indeed: Job openings index now back to pre-pandemic levels (-35% from peak)  BLS: Hiring rate has fallen to the lowest level since 2008‚Äì09  When three independent sources line up like this, it‚Äôs hard to ignore. Something is clearly breaking under the surface.  But here‚Äôs the twist: layoffs are still historically low, so the unemployment rate hasn‚Äôt moved much. At the same time, GDP growth and stock prices are still high. That‚Äôs why it doesn‚Äôt feel like a recession yet.  The impact I‚Äôm watching most closely is on housing. As job losses pick up and more households are forced to sell, housing demand will crack further. We‚Äôre already seeing a housing recession in half the U.S.‚Äîwith values dropping in places like Florida, Texas, and Arizona. The question is: how long before the pain spreads to other states?  üëâ Head to Reventure App  to track the data in your ZIP code. Pay close attention to inventory‚Äîif it‚Äôs spiking in your market, that‚Äôs a leading sign the recession is already underway, and cheaper home prices could be just around the corner.  Website: https://www.reventure.app Apple Mobile: https://apps.apple.com/us/app/reventure-app/id6736954854 Android Mobile: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.reventure.mobileapp&hl=en_US

commentText: Interesting data on the job market as it shows Therapists leading with job growth. I'm a Licensed Psychotherapist in California and for the past 10 years I have tried to convince a few family/friends to get in the field. We enter the job market around $85k and at 5 years around $140k. I've been a therapist 16 years and can easily clear $200k+ all from the comfort of my home, thanks to covid forcing insurance companies to offer therapy via video. I encourage anyone who has a passion for helping others to consider the field. As long as there are people breathing, we will always be needed, and Ai cannot replace therapists or psychiatric evaluations. The ONLY downside, 9 years of schooling and clinical rotations to become an independent Licensed Psychotherapist, but it's definitely worth it!

commentText: Something I haven‚Äôt heard a lot about is the rise in popularity of the 401k. In 2008/09 many companies / us govt had retirement plans (pensions) for their employees. Now a lot of that has been replaced with 401ks and a lot of those people (my self included) are simply maxing out their 401ks which is keeping the stock market growing every day.

videoTitle: The U.S. Recession is finally here.
videoDescription: ADP just released a shocking job market report, showing that employers shed 32000 jobs in September, signaling that we are ...
commentText: The Stock market is driven by one thing: index funds / 401(k) plans.  It is the check box on your payroll.  Most people are doing the "smart thing" and checking "put my 401k into an index fund."  It is like a steamroller that does not care what the market does or what the fundamentals are doing.  It is DUMB MONEY.  I can only imagine what the pension managers are thinking as they have spent all that payroll money on an already inflated market and huge bubble.  At some point, when the number of people unemployed grows and the funding stream has less money, the redemptions will exceed the incoming funds, and we are all in for a trillion-dollar disaster.  Like the student loan fiasco brought to you by Congress, which removed the bankruptcy option, this mess is also of congressional making.

commentText: The job market is rough right now but here is what I believe about some job seekers.  I used to believe that I deserved a six figure salary. Over time I really humbled myself and realized at my current skill I would be extremely lucky to get 70k. I came to realize theres a lot left to learn and experience to gain. I think its important for people to humble themselves and admit their own gaps in knowledge. Some people ive met think they deserve the most without even knowing the minimum. Its almost delusional. I dont say this to put people down but just be real with yourself and properly evaluate your skill level and potential. That way, you can open yourself to learn deeply. Like they say, the first to fixing a problem is realizing there is one.
