commentText: As I've said in previous posts.  The reason why you're perception of developers is that they're not technical enough is because for the last 15+ years the industry has pushed money into nothing but web apps and had a de-emphasis on hardcore computer engineering.    Now that the market is less liquid in terms of broad based investments companies are focusing dollars into he truly difficult tasks.  The issue will continue to manifest so long as companies do not document the technical aspect of their products and MOST importantly develop a talent pipeline for engineers to be trained in.

Everything is going well, then I get to the technical interview with engineers that have no business conducting interviews, they then rapid fire technical questions at me one after the other across all facets of topics like networking, OSs, playbooks, workflows, specific command line args for tools, obscure disk forensics questions, and anything else that comes to mind.  It‚Äôs like they don‚Äôt want to ask situational questions which is more my role, and they try to trip up applicants.  Like I already have the certs, I don‚Äôt memorize everything at this point in my career.

commentText: How do I get in touch with this recruiter, C/C++ is sort of a hobby language for me? I've never had much professional use of the language outside of side projects but I do have understanding of the fundamentals of C/C++ and fundamental programming concepts, but I also lack a strong knowledge in networking, concurrency (to the best of my understanding, concurrency has to do with the concept of simultaneous execution and can be applied to scenarios like I/O bottle-necks and video game scenarios where two or more objects are active at the same time period) and some of the more complicated concepts within general systems programming  (systems has quite a vast range of terminology and concepts so there's bound to be topics I've never heard before).   I'm more of a learn by doing rather than a learn by being shown/demonstrated most of the stuff I remember because I did it not because someone told me like with unique and shared pointers, move semantics and references. commentText: Go for the post grad (bachelors) internship. I did this with a public health lab and they just decided to keep me on. Most companies will use them as direct hire programs since they literally get to try you out for 4 months and train you at a discounted rate. It‚Äôs a no brainer. If you get an internship you most likely will be hired after. They let me work part time while I finished up my final semester as well. Internships are key.

commentText: If you are experienced and been working a long time and got laid off, and can't find comparable pay jobs or having trouble finding any jobs, this is what it means, it means your skill set isn't in demand, simply they the employer can either do it without you, which means your skills are not even needed, or they can find someone way cheaper to do the same, which means your skills are not that good if they find a 20 year old do the same for half of the salary.  And you can't get a job because you feel need a certain salary comparable or more than before, no one is going to off that, at least the offer will not exceed Cost of Living adjustment, if that is even added to the offer. What you have left is TWO choices, first, go acquire skill set that is in demand, not necessary more school or degrees. You need to do whatever it takes regardless working hours and pay to get that skill, even if you need to volunteer just to learn the skill then do it. Second,  the MSM will never tell you or promote it, is to become your own boss and finally take the risk and become an entrepreneur. Both choices will not be easy, they will be extremely hard, but not harder than what you are going through right now. So make the choice and start today.

commentText: Here is what I did/am doing to make it. I put everything I had down on my home in 2021 so I would have a lower pmt( I put down 42%) I love my house- it gives me peace of mind.  In order to afford my holistic health care, I have zero subscriptions, keep my heat at 64 degrees in the winter, never eat out, shop for a better deal each time insurance companies send out renewals at a higher rate.  I work at home so I have no travel or clothes expense.  My cell phone is on my sons plan, so I only pay $10/month.  I haul my garbage to my sons house, my cell phone is 5 years old, my computer is 9 years old.  Only eat out twice a year- my son takes me out for mothers day and my birthday.  In between, I only buy pizza takeout twice a year- nothing else. I cook from scratch.   I get my hair cut every other month along with a basic pedicure( not a luxury- left leg was injured in an auto accident so I cant reach my left foot) I color my own hair every 6 wks with a natural tint- less than $8 each time. I don;t wear jewelry, little makeup and no nail polish.  My neighbor pays a man called Kevin to have my grass cut on one side that borders her lawn ,so I bake for her since she has no family.  Kevin is retired and had a stroke so I also bake for him.  He loves the baked goods so much he comes on my property and uses a weed whacker to take care of weeds.  Probably not a savings since I use all organic ingredients and I bake for every holiday, 8 times a year but then I am not calculating tit for tat. I go to free concerts in the park , city council meetings and family gatherings in order to get out several times a month.  I cant afford a dog with proper vet care, grooming and providing REAL food, so I feed, water and provide housing for the feral cats (racoons visit sometimes) I buy a highly nutritious kibble with MEAT as first ingredient and put out leftovers which the animals love.  Nothing goes to waste.  The high quality products that I love can be ordered at Walmart online- they don't carry these items in the store.  I buy my meat from a local rancher -free range, grass fed-grain finished at a much lower price than Whole Foods. Vacations are only dreams. Because of all of this, even though I haven't had a raise in 3 yrs, ( Mgt can still hire for less than they pay me) I am able to support my favorite charities, slowly fix up my house and stock pile for uncertain days.  I have a business ready to start this summer.  I also have invested in commodities since 2009.  If my commodities keep on rising , I am hoping to finally quit my job and work my business part time next year.

commentText: I have a couple of issues with this discussion. First of all, they've completely ignored the elephant in the room. Companies are hedging their bets towards accelerated automation with A.I., whether the predictions pan out or not, hence  the precarious hiring processes. It's all over the news. This doesn't represent the entirety of the problem, but it definitely shouldn't be ignored. The harsh reality is that employees are a financial liability and a necessary evil to business owners, and if a cheaper, more reliable option exists, they will be foaming at the mouth to take it. If you look at the trend of entry level roles requiring say, 8 years of experience for example, that's a tell to indicate they might be automating away the 'true' entry level roles to A.I. So really, these are not entry level roles at all.  Second, Mitch did make a great point about not posting TikTok videos like this. Granted, it's a bad look and I totally agree that it's cringe, but let's be real, social media is so saturated with these videos anymore, nobody cares, really.  And the way we consume media is constantly changing. In 50 years TikTok will probably be replaced with something else ten times over, so the stuff people post today will go the way of polaroid photos, stuffed in a shoebox somewhere, or the digital equivalent. Sure, it's out there. But really, who cares?    Third, farming college graduates into the restaurant industry is probably a bad idea. The whole reason people go to college is so that they can get a professional job that pays a salary and benefits, and have a shot at an actual career trajectory. Part of what causes career stagnation is not landing a job in their field right out of the gate. The more time that passes before they get that first job, the wider the skills gap grows, and the less likely they'll ever escape the gig work grind. So yeah, spending a couple of years waiting tables when you have a degree in engineering could be the death nail for your career. Your education continues with that first job, and without it, you fall behind. That's why internships are such an essential component of the career ladder. You need to keep your education fresh, and if you take too long of a break, it's over.   Lastly, people who quit their job without another one lined up were probably in the wrong job in the first place. Their physical and mental health are likely in the toilet from burnout, so they are in total fight or flight mode. Going to work is becoming physically painful for them. Something like 80% of people are either not satisfied or actively disengaged with their work as it is. If you would rather starve than continue to go to work, that could be a symptom of a much larger and systemic problem. Anyone who can sit there and say, 'Don't quit your job without another one lined up', maybe has some survivorship bias. They're probably one of the lucky few who are actually satisfied with their position in life. I don't necessarily think it's bad advice, but anyone who is set in their mind on quitting their job without a fallback position is already so far gone that simply telling them not to quit is just pushing them to do it all that much faster. It's like reverse psychology. By saying don't jump, you're basically daring them to do it. I just think that a little more validation and understanding for people in this situation is in order here.

commentText: I've lived in Dallas most of my life and have always had one piece of advice for those relocating here or thinking about it. _Live as close as you can to your workplace._ I know someone with a perfectly good car who got a place on a bus line that doesn't require a transfer. It's a 30 minute trip which drops her off right in front of her office building. STAY AWAY from South Oak Cliff, Pleasant Grove, Five Points, Forest & Audelia, West Dallas and the SW part of NW Dallas. In fact, try to stay out of Dallas proper altogether. (Don't get me started.)

commentText: Ive been homeless half of my life. I am autistic. If anyone knows what autism is its how you see the world around you. Working everyday for any amount of money never made any sense to me. "Working" is enjoyable only if its to work toward something. Instead of working for money I work for food shelter entertainment and a shower. I choose when I want to work. If I dont work I dont eat. So Pretty much work everyday and that is natural to me. But this consumerist and capolistic society never made sense to me. Things have no value to me. The only things that have value to me are what I need to survive. I wish everyone thought the way I did. I wouldnt feel so lonely and excluded from society.

commentText: I was recently rejected from a position that I applied for, which I found on LinkedIn.  I had 2 meetings: one with the recruiter and then with the hiring manager. He said it was because I didn't "smile enough during the interview".  He said I seem too serious and that I might be too authoritarian in working with people.   I'm glad he called me back and gave that feedback, but I don't feel like I'm that type of person.  At least he called me back because most companies obviously don't do that very often and just send a rejection email.  Again, it goes back to what Brian is saying that companies are hyper-picky and will wait for that perfect candidate.  We are in a white collar recession.

commentText: I am 55 and have been in the professional work force since 1990. This is one of the worst job markets I have seen, and it is true the the job cycle is shorter now but what the video doesn't really offer is any kind of hope. Essentially what he is saying is, not only is it a bad market but you have to be perfect to get the next job. While all of that is true, its true now and it might not be true next year or the year after. This will cycle back to a positive hiring market, the question is to what degree and how fast. If you have a job keep it, now is a horrible time for a move. The economy is recovering from years of covid, high inflation and whack a mole tariffs. The best advice I can offer is build your network, the person you meet at work today might be the person that gets you in the door to your next role in 2028. EVERYONE at work is a potential lead for your next job. My prediction? 2026 things improve slowly. Hang in there.

commentText: It's a nearly impossible job market, but some people are still getting through. Work as hard as you can to be one of them. If you've never researched the companies you're applying to, now is the time to start. One of the jobs I've gotten was because I researched the company thoroughly and talked with the CEO about some of the articles he had written. They had one opening, but hired two people. I got the "extra" job.  This will cycle back around. Job searches themselves have changed forever, but the search environment is always a cycle of up, followed by down, followed by up again. We can build our networks, do the research, and break through, even if it takes a while.

videoTitle: The REAL Reason Why Getting A Job Is So Difficult Right Now
videoDescription: The REAL Reason Why Getting A Job Is So Difficult Right Now. If you're having a hard time getting a job or even a job interview, ...
commentText: I lucked out, recently.  I found a job in early September that's on the lower end of what I would accept for a salary, but it checks all of the boxes.  And it isn't another "contract" position, I was hired on directly which is a blessing from the heavens.  It probably helps that I work for a smaller company that (loosely) meets my 10+ years in the industrial manufacturing field.  And it took me 7 months to land this job.  Almost every job in a large urban area is through a staffing agency.  They'll "hire" you but typically don't ever offer any work.  I ended up with 4 who never gave me anything, including one prospect for a contract position that interviewed me.  It seemed to go very well, but then the company offering the contract and the agent both went dark.  I swear, the job search "market" has become an enormous extortion racket in the U.S.  Just like most everything else.
